title: I like this app
text: I needed a new email address so I could be more professional while job hunting & found out that I can use multiple email accounts in this app. So now I can have my poor old high school email side by side with my brand new business email. They are easy to switch between & the adds are easy to ignore if you don‚Äôt want to look at them. I understand why it needs adds so it doesn‚Äôt bother me any. This app even works better than checking my email through a internet browser for me. It loaded years of old emails & was easy to delete things I just never kept up with.

title: Great app, but missing features
text: I am really enjoying this app on my iphone and iPad. It is making my life much easier and works much better than the web version. However there is a feature that is missing in the app which is kind of important for my use. The app does not allow me to edit or delete calendar appointments. I can create them, but once they are created, I cannot change them. This made it frustrating this morning when I needed to reschedule an appointment with a client this morning because I then had to log on to the web version to delete the appointment. Other than this, I am very much enjoying using this app. Once this feature is added, I will update my review to 5 stars.

title: What happened to this app???
text: This used to be a great app. All of the updates are making it worse! I connect my work and personal gmail account through here and it used to have no problem distinguishing between only my work emails sending notifications and appearing in focused email section. Now all of my unimportant personal gmail emails are mixed in with my work emails in focused section and it shows I have 30 unread focused emails instead of 5 that really matter. Once I delete or look through these ‚Äúfocused‚Äù emails it‚Äôs still showing I have multiple unread emails when I leave the app. I then go back in the app and nothing is there! I shouldn‚Äôt have to delete my gmail account from this service to solve this so I am deleting the app all together. Makes no sense to have an app that can‚Äôt handle multiple email accounts when they promote that as one of their capabilities.

title: MSN explore versus outlook
text: Giving up MSN explore for me is not found to be easy simply because I‚Äôve been using it for many many years. Easy to navigate with everything you need all in one browser outlook in most cases it is better than the Explorer but when it comes to navigation it is so different from explore that I lose track i.e. i.e. address book where is the link? My thoughts are the address book is included in the folders. Just can‚Äôt get a clear understanding. I‚Äôve been jumping back-and-forth between the two browsers so it‚Äôs been a slow learning process for me. I am a premium subscriber to MSN  explore for many years. I suppose it‚Äôs time to change over to outlook,  if I should decide to stay with them.

title: Why I use Outlook!!
text: I have been using Outlook way back  in the early days when I first set up my Email with ‚ÄúHotmail‚Äù which we all now know is Outlook!!! I have nothing but praise for Outlook!! Whenever I run into baffles and/or I am stuck or having issues with my emails, and I am not receiving my emails because they are somewhere in La La land, the I T Staff out there for Outlook are a group of wonderful professionals who get right on the ball to help me and my staff out and will help resolve the issue at hand and I have had many opportunities to change my Email Server, but then I ask myself‚Ä¶.., ‚ÄúPatty, why change Email Server and Calendar Appointments

title: Very impressed
text: I love how well I can do my work using this app. I love how well all the windows apps work together too. Got an attachment? Forward it to your word app. Got a to do list? Get the to do app. Your list is visible in the outlook app! And cross things off or add things to your list right then and there in the outlook app. Calendar? Right there in the app. And don‚Äôt forget Teams! I‚Äôm so impressed and so bad at organization that I really appreciate that this app can do it for me. Only thing I need is more symbols for the calendar meeting types! Tell your job to invest in outlook it‚Äôs so worth it. I only mentioned a fraction of the apps it comes/works with.

title: decent
text: better than the iOS app, but still missing features. if you have a ton of folders, it'll take forever finding them. if you need to open your sent mail, you'll have scroll past all your folders before you'll get to it. if you‚Äôre a  moderators on any distribution list, you can't approve emails in this app. This is very disappointing.  The focused / other mailbox is awesome. I would be satisfied if the standard sent, junk, drafts, etc folders appeared above the folders I created. Appearing at the bottom is horrible. Lastly, if you use search folders in the desktop version of Outlook, they don‚Äôt appear in this app which also is annoying.

title: Great app but lacks some features when compared to the windows version
text:
I‚Äôve used outlook on my windows laptop and my iOS devices. The iOS version lacks a lot of features that the windows version has. I want to keep using Outlook but it might be easier to switch at this point unless they add some things to the iOS app. 

For example, you cannot access other people‚Äôs calendars/schedules on the iOS app like how you can on the windows version. You can create your own calendar but you can‚Äôt view anyone else‚Äôs in order to schedule meetings. It would also be nice to have a ‚Äúread all‚Äù feature for the iOS app to read everything in your inbox.

title: Mail on iPhone Better
text: Appointments randomly disappear of my outlook calendar and if I know which one it is and search it will find it and put it back on the calendar.  If you have places you have to be DO NOT RELY ON OUTLOOK APP ON IPHONE.  30 day calendar show nothing Apple mail app better.  No 30 day calendar in horizontal view.  No integration from other apps to outlook Apple Mail App way better.  Apple mail apps let me see all appointments from all calendars not just outlook ones.  Don‚Äôt like Microsoft sorting my mail and not being able to see my folders if I want.  Whole GUI blows compared to Apple Mail free app.  Keeps repeatedly crashing when it opens.  Disappointing app that for some insane reason company has started forcing me to use.  Will probably start using my own email account to avoid it, or maybe switch companies that‚Äôs how disappointed I am.

title: Personalized email stopped working
text: I‚Äôm giving three stars specifically because the inbox stopped receiving emails to my personal email account. Tried everything online to fix the issue but was experiencing said issue across all my devices not just one computer or device. Let me to believe that this was not just an issue on my side but on the server-side at Company location. Additional reason why three stars was only given because customer support has exclusively moved online which did not help me at all. Still feel that a live customer support technician was needed or is needed in the future to assist in hard to explain/fix technical issues. Don‚Äôt get me wrong outlook is a very good product in my opinion.

title: Worst App support Ever
text: This is a great app as long as it works. God help you if you encounter a problem with it and need help. Microsoft will not provide any phone support or even chat support for this app .   They wash their hands of it. The contacts in the app no longer synchronize with iOS contacts. I‚Äôve spent countless hours trying to fix this. The only support I‚Äôve received is from Apple. I am a paying office365 customer,  And I‚Äôve received very little actual meaningful help from Microsoft. Countless hours on hold, nights spent on useless chats with techs that don‚Äôt understand their own product.  If this is the support Microsoft provides paying customers, its time to dump the MS platform. Garbage support.

title: Doesn‚Äôt Show Email Addresses?
text:
For some reason (most likely aesthetics and to save space) it seems there is no way to have this app display the email address that incoming emails were sent by. This is my main sure fire way of identifying which emails are illegitimate phishing attempts and which are genuine. From what I can‚Äôt tell it‚Äôs literally not even possible to view the email addresses of received items in this app *at all*. Why? I want to use this app, it otherwise seems very convenient, but missing this basic functionality is simply a dealbreaker...

Edit: I found out how to display the addresses and increased my stars as a result. I still think the email addresses should be shown by default, however‚ÄîWere choosing aesthetics over basic safety here, in my opinion.

title: Useless
text:
This app has number of issues that make it very difficult to use if not useless:
1) it downloads only a set number of emails into the app and when you try to search for an email it searches the oldest emails in your account first (I.e. on the sever) so imagine how long it takes to get a result with recent emails. You will be waiting for a while. Then, the results are not comprehensive like in the Apple‚Äôs Mail app. These two things render this app useless.
2) Outlook gives you an option to link in calendars but it won‚Äôt link to your default iOS calendar that‚Äôs on your iPhone. Microsoft will tell you to sign in with your iCloud email account to link it but I don‚Äôt have iCloud email account but yet I have iOS calendar that I use and need. Other competing apps ( ex. Calendars) link up to iPhone‚Äôs calendar w/o any iCloud log ins and work wonderfully. Outlook will only work with calendars that‚Äôs in your email, eg Gmail.
3) customer support leaves a lot to be desired and is a hit and miss. Some responded right to the point, others don‚Äôt by giving you the typical half answer that we came to get accustomed from customer service in foreign countries that CS is being outsourced to. 

I‚Äôm still on search for a solid all around email/calendar app that can support iOS calendar and gmail accounts.

title: Yeah, I Didn‚Äôt Really Need to Do Tasks Anyway
text:
The greatest feature of Microsoft Outlook is the ability to use your email to create tasks. It‚Äôs a brilliant way to clear out your inbox without feeling that you‚Äôve forgotten to take care of business. Just create a task and it appears in your list, then archive the email and your inbox is now wonderfully manageable. When you go back and click on the task, viola! It brings up the related email and you can get right to work. Such a brilliant feature. 

Oh, but this is the Quadriplegic Version of Oulook. You can check your emails... but that‚Äôs about it. You can‚Äôt see your task list. You cannot turn your emails into tasks. It‚Äôs like cutting off the best part of a thing for fear that it might become too successful. Is it that Microsoft feels that they need to throttle down features on Apple platforms because they don‚Äôt want to give people yet another reason to ditch their PCs for Mac products? 

Handicapping one of your brightest children isn‚Äôt the right thing to do, either, however.  Look for the win-win. Find the workaround. You could have the number one mail app in the ios store hands down. You could charge $20 a pop for it, and we would all pay for it. But no. 

You felt it would be a better idea to take a hammer to it‚Äôs kneecap.

title: It has an ‚ÄúEdge‚Äù over Chrome
text:
I had been a Chrome user for years but in the last few, I‚Äôve had it just close on me; although I could just open it up again and restore my previous pages, it became super irritating. I kept using it because I didn‚Äôt want to take the time to switch over to Edge (thinking it would somehow be time-consuming to switch). I was wrong.
Anyway, recently purchased a new laptop and right out the gate, set everything up with Edge. Not one single issue. I still use Google apps but through Edge, not Chrome.
It‚Äôs been a great experience so far. Great job‚Ä¶ thank you!

title: It‚Äôs making life harder than it should
text: This is the second major complaint since installing this app. I work at an office where outlook is our main form of communication. We have offices in different parts of the country. If a mistake is made sending, creating or editing correspondence, that person suffers. For instance, when I tapped on a date the was in an email and it asked me to ‚Äúsave the date‚Äù in my calendar, I thought, SURE! Little did I know it would automatically create a frickin event and invite everyone in the email list to something I created!! It wasn‚Äôt even correct!!! I‚Äôve had other irritations with this app, but I am forced to use it for my job. Please make this thing a little more fool proof, if you can?

title: Doesn‚Äôt Work Many Times.
text:
I‚Äôm not that pleased with the app. I use Outlook for work and my job involves moving around a lot with various tasks, however, many people still need to email me about projects and needs so I need access to it at all times. 
For some reason, I will receive notifications consistently all day (like I‚Äôm supposed to) but then it will stop sending me notifications about emails and I think that no one has reached out to me until I get to my desk and see a pile up of emails on my desktop. 
Also, it is frustrating when I save a draft on my desktop to view later on my phone and it will not pull up or even show that there is a draft in my email. Same thing with sent and received mail. Some things I can view and some things I can‚Äôt. 
Very inconsistent and inconvenient. 
Needs improvement.

title: Amazing!
text: After trying out Outlook for macOS, I wanted to see how the iOS equivalent matched up. I don‚Äôt usually write reviews, but I just had to commend Microsoft‚Äôs development team for this incredible app. I have used Apple Mail since I have been using iOS, and while it has been great and easy to use, Outlook takes things a step further. It realizes and blends perfectly with the iOS interface, making it feel like this is a first-party Apple app. The integration of the calendar and seamless sync between my Google and iCloud accounts further proves that Outlook is a premier mail AND calendar client that every iOS user should be happy to use. Thank you Microsoft!

title: Good but can be better
text:
Search and move: I need to be able to select multiple emails from a search result and move them to an exchange folder.

Threads: unable to thread with SMIME enabled. Even if you can‚Äôt successfully thread an encrypted chain, let everything else thread to make reading email easier. Or thread by recent subjects where headers cannot be read. (More on this next)

Also on threads: MaaS360 threaded by subject and make it so easy to group hourly system alerts together so I can see them all in one. Outlook fills up my inbox full of alerts spread out and makes it very difficult to find or see regular email among the noise. And since I cannot select them all from a search result, I cannot sweep them away after review like I can with MaaS360.

While I don‚Äôt like MaaS360 email overall, it definitely has advantages over Outlook Mobile with regards to how it threads email subjects together and being able to move groups of email from a search result. Please improve these features to make accessing and moving large volumes of email easier for us system administrators who get tons of email every day.

title: Poorly designed app
text:
To get this right all the developers had to do was mirror  Outlook for Windows.  Instead they decided to make each feature less useful.

For example, how does one integrate tasks with the calendar.  In Windows, you can place tasks on the same screen your calendar.  On your Mac, all you get is the daily list of Events.  The developers could not distinguish between events and appointments.

Where is a command for ‚ÄúGo To‚Äù to a specific date.  Their Go To takes you to the various functions within the calendar-a feature listed in te bottom left hand corner.  Why bother?   If I want to see a date, in say, 1965, I have to keep clicking months from the present month 56 freakin‚Äô years.

And...enter a birthday.  No...not directly in the app.  Go to Outlook on the Web for Mac.  Enter your new birthdate by creating a new contact.  Don‚Äôt add a birthdate to an existing contact.   That doesn‚Äôt work. Think you got it now?  When you sync to Outlook for Mac the birthday shows over two days, or as the next day totally ignoring the correct date.   THIS PROBLEM HAS EXISTED FOR TEN YEARS.  They can‚Äôt fix it.

Then I wonder who owns this problem, Apple or Microsoft?  Ask the support staff. They will not answer.

Fantastical & Google are far superior and more user friendly.  This is junk.

title: Absolute garbage.
text: I don't know what all these great reviews are about, Outlook has caused me nothing but trouble. I've had to delete and reinstall the app twice because I stopped receiving emails (important emails I cannot afford to miss.) I also can't open additional inboxes when I use Outlook on my laptop, and instead receive an error message. Every time. I've tried to sign out and sign back in to my other email so I can view my inbox but once I type the second email, it takes me to a page where I need to provide my password, only to greet me with my first email. I can't even do a simple thing like sign out and sign back in so I can view different inboxes. Outlook is absolute garbage and has caused me WAY more trouble than any other email service. Gmail is the best email provider ever and I highly recommend using it to save you hours of headaches and frustration and missed emails.

title: Works well.
text: Seems to me everything works pretty well.  Syncs between my mobile devices and desktop properly.  There are just a couple of things that I think need work.  There is no ‚Äúselect all‚Äù or ‚Äúempty folder‚Äù button on the trash bin that I have found.  You must permanently delete items one at a time which can be a real pain.  It also will not filter appointments that are duplicated on multiple calendars.  A good example is holidays but also is the same for any appointment.  Occasionally I wind up with multiples of the same item on my calendar. Not life threatening but a nuisance just the same. It should be smart enough to recognize duplicates and ask whether you want to display all of them or not.

title: Good app but missing something critical
text:
I like the overall appearance and functionality of the mobile app with one major exception: I cannot see the number of unread messages in subfolders. The only folder I have surface level visibility on in the ‚Äúhamburger‚Äù menu view is Inbox. I work in IT and have a lot of rules running since I get thousands of automated email alerts a day and I heavily rely on the ability to quickly see which items need attention. I would love to see this functionality implemented. Unless there‚Äôs a simple setting perhaps I‚Äôm overlooking.

Edit: It appears this number appears/updates once I open the folder however I cannot verify if this necessary everytime I want to see the number of unread messages. If so, that is still very inefficient.

title: Overall good
text:
Overall I think the Outlook app is superior to the standard iPhone Mail app. Combining mail, calendar, and a robust search in one place is much more convenient and efficient than switching apps. However, to get to 5 stars, the send/receive delay needs to be improved and most times when I click on a recent mail notification, the message takes too long to load or I must kill the app to get it to load. Also, swipe customization is limited. I don‚Äôt flag messages and would prefer to have the option to delete or use categories with a swipe.

Again, overall it‚Äôs a better app but the small things add up.

title: It‚Äôs better than most alternatives
text:
I am an iOS user as well as a Windows user. The Windows version is very nice but the synchronization of contacts and calendar functions is cryptic and pretty hit or miss across different work stations, platforms and email accounts. This could be improved a lot, I think.

The iPhone configuration I'm using has some weird issues. I keep having to reset my account in order to see what is under the message headers and I have difficulties viewing or opening email attachments. When it‚Äôs all working well it‚Äôs way better than Mail on the iOS platforms.

title: Focused inbox doesn't filter correctly any more
text: I used to love this app.  Until recently.  The app used to reliably segregate emails from retailers, publishers, etc into the "other" box, and only put personal and obviously important emails in there "focused" inbox. I might get 3-5 focused emails per day. Something changed and I now get 30-40 so called focused emails with corresponding alerts each day. I have diligently marked each one "always move to other" but they continue to flood my focused inbox. I have contacted support, and to their credit they are sympathetic and try to help, but nothing has solved the problem. They now suggest blocking the senders but sometimes I want the offers or coupons. I just don't want to be alerted every time one arrives, and I don't want to sift through them to find the few emails I want to know about every time.

title: Just Ok but tremendous upside if a few items are addressed
text:
I LIKE this email application, but I don‚Äôt LOVE it as most others seem to. Here‚Äôs why:

1. Email functionality is ‚Äúgood‚Äù but not great. The fact that I am not automatically taken to my next message once I delete or archive an email is a huge deal for me (and others as well according to feedback on another social platform‚Ä¶go ‚Äúread it‚Äù)

2. Calendar function is ‚Äúgood‚Äù, but again, not great. Other Calendar applications give you the options to add ‚Äútravel time‚Äù to and from events/appointments so Microsoft‚Äôs excuse that Apple doesn‚Äôt allow this anymore for 3rd party apps is confusing to me

3. The recent update (6/1/21) broke the app, at least for. It crashes almost as soon as it attempts to open. 

If the issues above are addressed or additional features are added this has the potential to be one of, if not THE best email application on the App Store. Until then, I can only give this 3 stars as it is a ‚Äúgood‚Äù email alternative, not a ‚Äúgreat‚Äù one.

title: Overall a good app but the people section needs improvement
text:
I‚Äôve been using the app daily for the past few years and overall like it and recommend it. 

The area that needs the most improvement has to do with finding and organizing people which is something I do frequently. You have to do too many taps to locate and edit people and it‚Äôs also rather confusing. Not sure why the email and calendar portion is given such prominence, but people management seems to be an afterthought. Also confusing is when you search for someone‚Äôs name it shows duplicate search results even if there‚Äôs only one record.

title: Stops refreshing email inbox when update is needed
text: I am so frustrated with this application because emails are not being sent or new emails are not being shown. After searching the cause, I came to find that if there are outstanding updates, the application will not refresh the inbox and may lag when trying to send emails. You will not know there is an update to the application unless you check the App Store. The application is updated so frequently and without any notice. This week the application updated 3 times! Every couple of days the application lags. I am now trained to check the App Store a few times per week just to be able to send and receive emails for work. I have not had to do this with any other application. Aggravating.

title: Push notifications don‚Äôt work with IMAP
text:
Overall I love Outlook. However, for months (maybe over a year from my first contact to support) iOS push notifications for IMAP accounts remain faulty. I contacted support, again, to advise that notifications don‚Äôt work right. In fact, sometimes I receive notifications 24 hours after arrival for emails which I have already read. Other times not at all. 
Support advised that developers are aware of issues, which is the feedback I received back when I previously contacted. It‚Äôs unfortunate that they don‚Äôt add an interval to fetch IMAP from the server (every X minutes, etc) or provide another solve to fix the issue. Please, please, please address whatever the root cause is for the delayed or undelivered notifications. Thank you!

title: Won‚Äôt work consistently
text: It does not stay connected on iPhone XS. Other reviews also have issues. Support always suggests deleting them adding accounts back but then it happens again. Every month I have to reload the email settings as it stops syncing, bugs such as not being able to delete emails, having to setup imap account details and add signatures back etc.  With four accounts, one in Outlook 365 and other three IMAP accounts  this has gotten too much every month. My guess is it‚Äôs tied to the month billing through 365. I‚Äôm going back to using the Apple mail app to setup my IMAP accounts.

title: Keyboard Issues
text: I would give this application a better review because I do generally like the interface, layout and overall functionality. However I have two issues. The first issue is with the keyboard. When trying to draft an email from the app the keyboard constantly closes itself as I‚Äôm typing. The second issue is with actually receiving emails. There have been several occasions where I have received an import email when using my computer but not had the time to immediately respond read or respond. Only to eventually find that once I‚Äôve gone mobile the email is no longer in my inbox. I cannot even find it using the search function. Once I return to the computer, miraculously it‚Äôs still there. This doesn‚Äôt happen often but enough to be extremely irritating and for me it‚Äôs only been to extremely important emails

title: Can‚Äôt live without Outlook
text: I‚Äôve never really liked using Yahoo and gmail services directly because they are so limited and inflexible. I have no idea how you would imbed a table, adjust margins, create folders, request a deliver/read notification, etc. in Yahoo or gmail. There is one feature of Yahoo I really find useful and that is the ability to search for subscriptions. It identifies the subscriptions,  indicates how often they send an email and allows you unsubscribe en mass! The thing is I ran across this feature once but have no idea how to find it again. Please add this feature to Outlook.

title: An overall good solution to sync business and personal e-mails
text:
Mostly this app is a positive experience.  I‚Äôve been on Windows for 25 years, so having no Windows mobile solution had some pains at first, but I enjoy the seamless transition between mobile and PC that the office suite of apps now offers.

I do run into sim issues with how threads are handled, in some instances it is not intuitive to access multiple e-mails within a single thread.  Also, some content isn‚Äôt always shown.  But for quick reference and checking on the go, this is a great solution.  The focused inbox helps me keep the important separated from the trash without additional work, but I know that is a personal preference that not everyone will share.

title: It‚Äôs great when it works.
text:
I‚Äôve had some significant malfunctions with this app for months and contacting support was a huge waste of time.  

When I add appointments on my Outlook calendar via my laptop, they don‚Äôt show on my mobile Outlook calendar. Additionally, I have been able to get notifications and I have to manually refresh the app to get my emails every time. I was in a chat with support for weeks, and they would just reply every few days asking me to update the app. Eventually I was upgraded to the next tier of support team and they told me there‚Äôs nothing they can do, just wait for the next app update. To be clear, my app is set to auto update and they continued to tell me to update regardless. 

When the app is working smoothly it‚Äôs great, but these malfunctions have lead to me missing appointments and time sensitive emails.

title: Missed emails, sneaky advertising
text: To begin with, I only installed this app because Microsoft snuck a download link into the body of an email from my employer. Really shady move there, and I should have uninstalled for that reason alone. I decided to try it out anyway because my coworkers recommended it. Since then, I have missed several important emails because I was overconfident in the app‚Äôs ability to perform its most basic function: to inform me I have new mail. It worked at first, which lulled me into a false sense of security. Apparently the app has now decided that messages from my employer aren‚Äôt important enough to warrant notifications. It also occasionally takes several hours longer to receive mail that I had already accessed through my computer. I‚Äôll be going back to the direct approach to email from now on, and I recommend anyone considering this app to do the same.

title: Great mail app but needs work
text:
I gave three stars because there are some issues to be resolved yet. 
For example: when searching you should be able to filter the results (has attachments, date range, etc..) which you can do easily on the pc but not the app. Searching for a date range is extremely difficult if not impossible which should be one of the main filters. 
Another issue, they keep removing and adding Teams add-on and should really stay installed. 
The biggest issue is attaching files of 35mb and over which it does not allow you to. In 2023, files are larger than ever and to email something in pieces is very difficult. 
Overall, Outlook is the best mail app for work.

title: I love it
text:
The iOS app is nicely integrated with my phone for alerts and calendar‚Ä¶ especially with so much being done in teams as well too.  The OneDrive integration has been INVALUABLE when I‚Äôm away from my work station and need to share something dynamically and collaborate. 

I use outlook for all things in my professional life and this app lets me read/reply/file/search email and calendar efficiently and easily. I appreciate that MS designed this app with a professional in mind. Since only use outlook for professional work it‚Äôs VERY easy for me to escape work when need be and engage my awareness at what ever depth feels right.

title: 2 years replaced
text: I‚Äôve have Outlook for iOS for quite sometime... very seamless replacement for the standard iOS mail app. My only gripe is the ghost notification badges. I am very particular about having all email checked and clearing out notifications. However, sometimes badge notifications stick around for a week or two after deleting/reading emails. They clear out after I open it, only to reappear a little later. I‚Äôve tried deleting recycle bin, checking draft folders, etc... but they still hang around for a while. Other than that minor issue that triggers my OCD‚Äîgreat email app!

title: Good, but, doesn‚Äôt support location-based reminders.
text:
Before making the switch to Outlook mobile, I got pretty used to creating Reminders like, ‚Äúremind me to do this thing after I get to work‚Äú. My phone would then remind me to do that particular thing only after my Geo location had reached my place of work. Made it really nice, since sometimes I wouldn‚Äôt go to work at the same time every day.

After essentially deleting the Apple calendar after installing Outlook on my phone, it became apparent that I was not able to do this anymore. I love everything else about this app, but if this feature were to be created it would be awesome.

title: Not a seamless transition between platforms
text:
I love the ease of checking/responding to work emails on the go. I hate that Microsoft developers have not addressed the clunky transition between the web and mobile platforms.

For instance, my signature is completely distorted when I send an email from my phone. Also, the font change! If I‚Äôm in a conversation on the web and continue on my phone, the recipients should not notice a difference. The web font is a nice arial (I think) and the mobile platform is times new roman. Unfortunately, there‚Äôs no way to correct this.

Imagine being involved in an email thread with pretty important people and some of your messages are 10 pt. font in a calming blue with a nice signature and some of your messages are in a clunky 12 pt. font in black with a skewed signature. It‚Äôs tacky and renders the mobile platform useless!

title: Mike
text: Outlook mobile app is very good except the search feature. I suggest you have a separate search feature for email, contacts and calendar. It is time consuming and frustrating that when I am looking at for a person‚Äôs name when searching contacts that I only see the first two contacts with only summary info and then emails with that name in it. I have to click a couple times to get detailed contact info. Also occasionally  I would like to search my calendar but when I do use the search feature now no calendar entries show on the mobile app. Please address. That should be relatively easy to do.  Thanks.

title: Now it functions like the website
text: It can be slow sometimes to load emails but other than that I can‚Äôt say anything negative about this app.  I‚Äôm glad they finally updated the app so that I can empty trash with just a button instead of pressing and holding then selecting all the emails in my trash folder and deleting.  I suppose the ads can be annoying because it shows up at the top of mail folder and it is indistinguishable from my emails.  Sometimes I will click on them by accident. title: This app is great, best mail client
text: I‚Äôve been using outlook for a while now and even when I use much more the web client, the app is very simple and easy to use. I like that I can protect my data using Touch ID and the design is clean and intuitive. I will strongly recommend you to integrate Microsoft to-do into this one, like in the web version, it would make the app much more productive. title: Works Okay
text:
I have an IPhone.  I was accessing my company email, contacts, and calendar through the I phone apps.  My company required us to use mobile outlook to access the company email server.  The email and calendar are accessed through the Outlook app.  These work OK.  My contacts were not syncing.  I had to search online to get outlook to sync the contacts.  The default is to not sync.  Outlook now syncs the contacts but it creates multiple copies of the contacts.  It got so bad that I had 40 copies of my contacts.  I had to go online to delete the multiple contacts out of my iPhone.

Contacts are critical and creating multiple copies is a problem.  Perhaps this is why syncing contacts is not enabled by default.

title: Attachments need to be debugged.
text:
I‚Äôve used this app for my account on my iPhone for years now. My biggest problem is when I go to files on my phone to add them as an attachment. Often after 2 added attachments, it gets really slow and buggy when adding more to the email. Sometimes so slow it almost crashes. It would be a great help if when adding files from my phone folder, that I could select multiple files to add at one time. 

Also, spam has been getting past the filter and into my inbox more regularly. 

Other than that I‚Äôd like the ability to send larger file sizes. This is a real problem sometimes.

title: Perfection
text:
Outlook is visually appealing and extremely practical, however the fact that I can‚Äôt move emails in between accounts to save them in different folders, and also that the images for the contacts don‚Äôt load the same way as they do in Mail, or in the Contacts app is rather silly. Why would outlook have a separate contacts database and not an extension of the already existing, in which photos emails, etc are all already saved and organized?

However, the ability to do certain things directly within the app, and the synchronization with calendar are fantastic.

Oh - another note: could we please be allowed to copy and paste events within calendar? Or at least have an auto-fill suggestion from previous events, like Apple does? If I have to type certain work events every day over and over again because they have the same info, but different times, it becomes a rather annoying task, when I could just copy and paste on different times, or start a new event with auto-fill info.

;)

title: Improvements needed to be a great app
text: There are a few crucial updates needed to make this a 5-star mobile mail application: Add originating inbox identifier for notifications in Notification Center for multiple inbox management: I manage 6 inboxes, not including my own, and I need to have an eye in each of them constantly. Being able to make the originating inbox distinction from the notification would be a top-tier improvement for people who oversee more than just their own inbox. Categories: WHERE ARE CATEGORIES? The web version of Outlook has these, To Do desktop uses these, Outlook desktop has this option and they all communicate with each other. This feature is ESSENTIAL. Bring it to mobile!

title: Problematic with iOS
text:
I wanted to use the Outlook app as my preferred e-mail program on my iPhone X because I enjoy using Outlook on my PC. Unfortunately, this app doesn‚Äôt work well with iOS. The functionality is just not there.

For example, users cannot Edit subfolders on the app (you have to log-in to Outlook online and configure your Folder hierarchy on a PC). The Outlook app allows users to create subfolders, but that‚Äôs it. Users can‚Äôt move, rename, edit, or delete subfolders.

There‚Äôs a long list of incompatibility issues I found annoying and tedious to work-around. I guess that‚Äôs to be expected from a free Microsoft app on a mobile device running iOS. I set-up all of my Microsoft Exchange e-mail accounts on the Apple Mail platform and it works seamlessly with my iPhone X Calendar, Notes, etc. (similar to Outlook‚Äôs functionality on my PC).
